channel.title: Privacy on Internet Freedom Foundation
channel.description: Recent content in Privacy on Internet Freedom Foundation

item.title: Explained: RBI's Account Aggregator Framework
item.description: The RBI’s Account Aggregator framework went live on 2nd September this year. The government has claimed that the framework will have a transformative impact on the financial ecosystem. In this explainer, we take a look at what this framework really is and highlight certain issues that may arise.

item.title: SC appoints a committee to examine the use of Pegasus Spyware in India
item.description: Supreme Court has appointed a committee of technical experts overseen by Justice R. V. Raveendran, to examine the use of Pegasus Spyware on Indian Citizens.

item.title: Illegal CCTV deployment in Delhi is alarming #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Lt. Governor of Delhi with our concerns regarding the ongoing illegal CCTV deployment in the National Capital and possible recommendations to protect the privacy of citizens.

item.title: MoUs for algorithms and data for profit: 4 new MoUs signed between the Ministry of Agriculture and private corporations, including Jio and Cisco.
item.description: The Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers’ Welfare has recently signed 4 more Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) agreements regarding the Agristack with Cisco, Ninjakart, ITC Limited, and Jio. In this post, we analyse these MoUs, and explain the issues that arise as a result.

item.title: Big Opportunity! CCI accepts IFF’s expert information in its investigation of WhatsApp’s 2021 Privacy Policy
item.description: IFF has submitted expert information before the DG of CCI in charge of the investigation into WhatsApp’s Privacy Policy. We highlighted how WhatsApp has a dominant position in the market, and how the Privacy Policy abuses such dominant position. The CCI tagged the information with the investigation.

item.title: IFF submits its comments on the Draft Aadhaar (Pricing of Aadhaar Authentication Services) Regulations
item.description: We have provided our comments on the Draft Aadhaar (Pricing of Aadhaar Authentication Services) Regulations 2021. In our comments, we recommended that Aadhaar authentication charges be scrapped and private entities be barred from acting as ‘requesting entities’ for authentication.

item.title: Read our Joint Letter with C-Help & FMES to NHA on CoWIN’s updated API #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the National Health Authority with C-Help & FMES on their updated API which would allow government and private entities to know the vaccination status of individuals.

item.title: Vaccination is essential; Vaccine passports are not! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: In this explainer on vaccine passports, we try to examine the ethical, legal and privacy concerns surrounding them.

item.title: CCTVs in Delhi: Cause for concern or celebration? #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Government of Delhi to highlight our concerns and highlight the need for a legal review & audit of their CCTV project.

item.title: MEITY filed a limited affidavit in Supreme Court without confirming or denying if the Government used Pegasus
item.description: The Government has filed a limited affidavit before the SC which proposes to constitute a Committee of Experts but does not categorically comment on whether the government used the Pegasus Spyware. The SC has heard submissions on the limited affidavit and has listed the case for 17.08.2021.

item.title: We wrote to the Govt. of Meghalaya against the use of FRT for verification of pensioner's identities
item.description: We provided support to Mr. Jade Jeremiah Lyngdoh, a law student, in drafting a letter to the Govt. of Meghalaya in which we highlighted the possible privacy concerns of using FRT to verification of pensioners' identity.

item.title: The Arsenal Reports: The rise of targeted surveillance in India
item.description: The reports by Arsenal Consulting show that some of the BK-16 were surveilled and incriminating documents planted on their computers. We analyse what this means for the rise of targeted surveillance in India in light of the recent Pegasus revelations.

item.title: Pegasus: Rupesh Kumar Singh and Ipsa Shatakshi and other journalists approach SC
item.description: Rupesh Kumar Singh and Ipsa Shatakshi, activists reporting on issues related to Adivasi people in Jharkhand, approached the SC asking to declare that the use of a spyware such as Pegasus is unconstitutional. IFF has provided legal assistance.

item.title: Line-by-line verification of the IT Minister's Statement on the Pegasus Hacks
item.description: In this post, we present to you a line-by-line verification of the IT Minister’s statement on Pegasus, wherein we use a constitutional, legal, and people-centric lens to debunk and correct falsehoods and misinterpretations.

item.title: State Governments need to step up on the Pegasus issue
item.description: Cognisant of the legal injuries as well as the violations of fundamental rights that have occurred in light of the Pegasus spyware revelations, we wrote to the state governments of Maharashtra & Chhattisgarh to institute investigations into the use of spyware against citizens.

item.title: Securing Examination Data: No Child’s Play
item.description: Concerned about the threat to children’s privacy and safety caused by such data breaches, in July 2021, IFF sent thirty-two representations to the State and Union Territory Commissions for the Protection of Child Rights in India.

item.title: Women’s safety on the internet has to account for intersectionality
item.description: In light of recent incident wherein women belonging to the Muslim community were targeted, we have written to the NCW & DCW with our recommendations as well as to GoDaddy.com asking them to remove the domain registered with them.

item.title: IFF’s Statement on Hacking Revelations made by the Pegasus Project
item.description: Read our statement in response to the revelations made by the Pegasus Project which revealed that over 300 verified Indian mobile telephone numbers were targeted by the Israeli spyware firm, NSO Group.

item.title: Government endorses the use of facial recognition for “touchless” vaccination process
item.description: We filed an RTI application with the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to verify reports about the government using facial recognition technology (FRT) for the verification of beneficiaries of the COVID-19 vaccines. In their response the Ministry confirmed the use of FRT.

item.title: Striking the balance between privacy and public interest in judicial proceedings: Our comments to the Supreme Court’s Draft Live Streaming Rules
item.description: Draft Model Rules for Live-Streaming and Recording of Court Proceedings were released by the Supreme Court’s e-Committee. IFF submitted its comments to the Draft Rules welcoming the Rules, and suggesting that the Rules can strike a better balance between privacy and public interest.

item.title: ClubHouse: How safe really is this 'safe space'?
item.description: In this post, we unfurl some of the key considerations Clubhouse must include while fostering a robust human rights framework for its rapidly growing millions of users.

item.title: Live and let Live: The Supreme Court releases draft rules for live streaming of court proceedings
item.description: The e-Committee has released draft rules for live streaming of all proceedings in all courts. We strongly welcome this step, and offer small changes which can further improve the Rules.

item.title: Madras High Court issues notice in petition challenging the Intermediary Rules 2021 by T. M. Krishna
item.description: Madras High issued notice on a writ petition by T.M. Krishna challenging the Intermediary Rules 2021.

item.title: Hyderabad Police force people to remove their masks before photographing them. We sent a legal notice. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Hyderabad Police is forcing people to remove masks and photographing them. We sent a legal notice to the Police Commissioner about this.

item.title: Cybersec Charcha: Understanding the booming ransomware industry
item.description: In the second edition of Cybersec Charcha, we are taking a deep dive into understanding the unregulated ransomware industry, what a ransomware attack means and the consequences it can have.

item.title: Despite CIC’s observation that MeitY's response to us was “grossly improper," MeitY issues the same response again #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: CIC directed the CPIO to re-visit our original RTI and provide a revised reply and info, if (comments on consultation on PDPB). However, the CPIO simply cited the same exemption under S.8 of the RTI Act that she had provided before the CIC.

item.title: Bad Rules for Good Governance
item.description: We explain why the Aadhaar Good Governances Rules are unconstitutional as they exceed the limits of the Aadhaar Act, violate the Puttaswamy judgement and proportionality test, and are vague and non-voluntary. We have petitioned the Committees on Subordinate Legislation to review the Rules.

item.title: We urge CBSE to consider the pandemic as a time for care for students, not violations of their privacy.
item.description: Read our analysis of CBSE’s response to our representation on facial recognition use on students for access to digital documents.

item.title: DNA Bill : On democratic processes and dystopian outcomes #IFFExplainer #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The Standing Committee on Science and Technology recently submitted its report on the DNA Bill. Several concerns have been raised over the report, with two Committee members filing dissent notes. We decided to provide an explainer that breaks down the key issues with both the report and the Bill.

item.title: Is internet access not a basic necessity? Should our privacy not be safeguarded in health and education?
item.description: While the emphasis laid on improving access and equity is commendable, there are certain concerns that the Economic Survey must address. These include questions raised about the commercialisation of healthcare and the viability of remote learning, as well as the overarching data paradigm.

item.title: A rose by any other name? CBSE's face matching technology is just facial recognition in disguise
item.description: Read our representation to CBSE highlighting the concerns that come along with the use of facial recognition technology which they have put in place for accessing digital documents.

item.title: Delhi HC issues notice to govt in petition challenging denial of RTI regarding Aarogya Setu #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Today, the Delhi HC issued notice to the CPIOs of DeitY, MeitY, NeGD and NIC in a petition filed by RTI activist, Saurav Das, challenging denial of information relating to the creation of the Aarogya Setu app.

item.title: Explainer: WhatsApp Privacy Policy Changes #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The new privacy policy confirms that Facebook may now have access to messages shared with businesses on WhatsApp and it provides more insight into expansive meta data collection by WhatsApp.

item.title: We wrote to the UGC and the Ministry of Education on exam proctoring
item.description: Following multiple reports of the use of exam proctoring technology by various universities across the country, we wrote to the University Grants Commission and the Ministry of Education.

item.title: Statement: IFF joins international civil society orgs to oppose the NSO Group’s attempt to evade responsibility for the Pegasus Hack #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: 8 civil society organisations from across the world including IFF have filed an amici brief before the Ninth Circuit Federal Court of Appeals in California urging the Court to dismiss the NSO Group’s appeal claiming sovereign immunity for the Pegasus hack.

item.title: The non-personal data policy process remains opaque and problematic #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Replies to Right to Information requests filed to the Committee of Experts working on the Non-Personal Data Governance framework highlight an underlying transparency problem which has been mirrored throughout 2020 by various other such data-related consultations by the Government.

item.title: Privacy Policies of Telecom Service Providers - Or Why You Shouldn't Just Click Accept
item.description: We analysed the privacy of policies of the 4 large telecom service providers to check not only whether they were Puttaswamy-compliant, but also whether they would need updating in the face of the Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019. We found certain alarming issues in these policies.

item.title: Comments on the Draft Social Security Rules to safeguard worker's rights #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The Ministry of Labour released the Draft Code on Social Security (Central) Rules, 2020. In our comments on the draft, we have highlighted the following issues: mandatory aadhaar based verification and inadequate security safeguards for employee databases.

item.title: Internal govt documents provide insight into the creation and expansion of Aarogya Setu #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Minutes of meetings of the 9th Empowered Group on Technology and Data Management provide an insider view into the creation and expansion of Aarogya Setu and other government data collection projects during the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: Project Panoptic: Right to Information Updates from Delhi Police, Kolkata Police and Telangana State Technology Services
item.description: Replies to RTI requests filed with the Delhi Police, the Kolkata Police and the Telangana State Technology Services shed light on how these public authorities are using their FRT systems.

item.title: Security incidents and the Personal Data Protection Bill. Need to do more and do better.
item.description: The recent BigBasket data breach was the most recent example of a spate of security incidents that have plagued the country recently. As work becomes more and more digital, the legislative framework for cyber security must be strengthened by strengthening the Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019.

item.title: Mandatory imposition of Aarogya Setu by Delhi Govt is illegal and ineffective #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Delhi Government and its Excise Department urging against mandatory imposition of the Aarogya Setu app. Our alarm bells were rung by a circular issued by the Excise Department which directed licensed wholesale liquor vendors to ensure mandatory use of Aarogya Setu by every worker.

item.title: IFF's Project Panoptic is (almost) here
item.description: The launch of the Project is imminent. Read more about the project here.

item.title: Statement: One year of inaction, delay and evasion on the NSO-Pegasus hack #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Despite multiple government and parliamentary bodies examining the Pegasus hack, a whole year has passed and we still do not know who was responsible for this egregious violation of the privacy of human rights defenders in the country.

item.title: Watch the Watchmen Series Part 5 : The Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019
item.description: In the fifth part of our “Watch the Watchmen” series, we take a closer look at PDP Bill which is likely to be tabled in next year’s Budget Session.

item.title: While India copes with COVID-19, Aadhaar continues its function creep #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: After the Aadhaar Amendment Act 2019 and the Aadhaar Good Governance Rules 2020, there remain virtually no limitations on the use of Aadhaar authentication, which had earlier been restricted by the SC to only government entities and only for receipt of benefits and subsidies.

item.title: Read our comments on the DoT's Paper to develop an Indian Artificial Intelligence Stack
item.description: Our main recommendation to the committee was to set up an independent supervisory data protection authority to regulate the stack.

item.title: We write to the Criminal Law Reform Committee which could make it even easier for TV anchors to read your texts #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Our submission reiterates demands to disband the Committee and we have also provided substantive inputs on various issues at the intersection of criminal law and digital rights.

item.title: Delhi HC directs govt to consider representation regarding national Health Data Management Policy #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The petition heard by the Delhi HC raised concerns about the unreasonably short deadline for submission of feedback at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, and highlighted how the existing process excludes persons with disabilities, non-English speakers and people without internet access.

item.title: Watch the Watchmen Series Part 1 : The National Intelligence Grid
item.description: We take a closer look at the proposed National Intelligence Grid which aims to tackle terror threats in the country and is scheduled go live on December 31, 2020.

item.title: Kerala HC to hear Aarogya Setu petitions in September 2020 #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: On 24 August, the Kerala HC heard a writ petition regarding third party data sharing and mandatory imposition of the Aarogya Setu app.

item.title: Explainer: Law enforcement access to personal electronic devices #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: This explainer is to help the reader navigate a situation where the police seize and intend to/or demand access to your personal electronic device (PED) such as a mobile phone, laptop, tablet, etc.

item.title: Over 130 individuals and organizations oppose mandatory use of Aarogya Setu in Delhi district courts #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The representation highlights that making Aarogya Setu a pre-condition to access judicial establishments is likely to create barriers to justice, compromise the privacy of lawyers and their clients, and lacks any basis in law.

item.title: Survey about use of Aarogya Setu for air travel #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Take this survey about use of Aarogya Setu for air travel so we can identify the scale of the problem and take appropriate remedial measures.

item.title: We wrote to DGCA with recommendations on the Draft Unmanned Aircraft System (Drones) Rules, 2020 #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Read our recommendations to the DGCA on the Draft UAS (Drones) Rules. Our main recommendations were the introduction of privacy protecting measures and the prohibition of aerial surveillance.

item.title: Bulk data sharing policy scrapped is an incremental victory that requires follow up action #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The MoRTH has scrapped its Bulk Data Sharing Policy. While this is a great step, there are a few critical privacy loopholes that still remain to be addressed. We wrote to the ministry identifying as well providing recommendations to tackle these loopholes.

item.title: Joint Statement : The Government of Kerala must withdraw compulsory Aadhaar for state government jobs
item.description: Kalyani Menon Sen, a petitioner in the Aadhaar case has sent a legal notice to the Government of Kerala which has made Aadhaar mandatory for state government jobs. We are issuing a joint statement supporting this action.

item.title: How (cyber)safe are the Indian citizens? Think again and think harder. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Committee on IT, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha, and the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha. We highlighted the presence of massive cybersecurity threats in India and the need for reinstating parliamentary deliberation for protecting citizens' rights.

item.title: The ongoing illegal use of drones for mass surveillance by the Delhi Police needs to be investigated #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the MCA and DGCA asking them to recall the conditional exemption allowing the use of drones for COVID-19 related operations and to commence an investigation into the ongoing illegal use of drones by the Delhi Police for mass surveillance.

item.title: Surveillance of social media users is not the solution for fake news #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We sent a legal notice to BECIL against a tender for procurement of fact verification and disinformation detection tools which will lead to mass surveillance of social media users.

item.title: Mass Surveillance? You decide as per DoT’s RTI responses #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: RTI responses received by IFF raise concerns about illegal mass surveillance and do not support DoT’s claim that bulk Call Data Records were sought for call drop analysis.

item.title: RWA uncles, please calm down about Aarogya Setu #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the government seeking issuance of an advisory which clarifies that Resident Welfare Associations cannot make use of Aarogya Setu mandatory for entry into housing societies.

item.title: Kerala High Court hears challenges against mandatory imposition of Aarogya Setu
item.description: The Kerala High Court has directed MeitY to file a response to petitions challenging mandatory imposition of Aarogya Setu and to state on record that data collected by the app will not be misused.

item.title: The Internet Should Not Become a Boys Club
item.description: We wrote to the WCD Ministry and DCW about the need to address image based sexual abuse on the internet in a rights respecting manner in light of the recent ‘Boiz Locker Room’ incident.

item.title: Workers of a digital world unite to advance privacy, dignity and autonomy! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: This May Day, IFF and a diverse group of individuals and organizations write to the government to ensure that privacy, dignity and autonomy of workers is not compromised during the COVID-19 crisis.

item.title: Unpacking the positives and risks of Apple and Google’s contact tracing foray #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF’s Working Paper on Privacy Prescriptions for Technology Interventions on COVID-19 in India, affords significant space to the issue of contact tracing technologies. It offers a preliminary breakdown of the Apple and Google’s proposed partnership to provide a digital contact tracing solution.

item.title: The need to investigate the NSO Group, which was behind the Pegasus software, is now more than ever. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Chief Ministers of Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh urging them to establish committees to investigate the Whatsapp hack. Our key recommendations were to include victim and expert testimony in the investigation which should be carried out in a transparent manner.

item.title: Read IFF’s Response to the Draft Competition (Amendment) Bill, 2020. Our Ask? Hold Big Tech Accountable
item.description: IFF responded to the Ministry of Corporate Affairs; draft Competition (Amendment) Bill, 2020 . We suggest ways in which the Government could strengthen and streamline its institutions. We also stress on the need for India’s competition laws to reflect challenges emerging from technology markets.

item.title: Data Protection and the National Population Register #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF’s brief highlights how NPR violates data protection principles of lawfulness, consent, purpose limitation, data minimization and accountability. Based on this case study, the brief identifies various loopholes in the PDP Bill and recommends necessary changes to the Joint Parliamentary Committee.

item.title: Lessons from the International Debate on Facial Recognition
item.description: We trace the international debate on use of facial recognition technology and recommend imposing a 3 year moratorium in India.

item.title: Problems with Facial Recognition Technology Operating in a Legal Vacuum
item.description: While the obvious problem with introduction of facial recognition in India is that a faulty system with a high error rate may be implemented, the implementation of an accurate FRT system also raises serious privacy concerns.

item.title: Introduction to Facial Recognition Projects in India
item.description: In the first of a three part series, we map major facial recognition projects being implemented by the Central and State Governments and broadly classify them according to intended purpose.

item.title: Workplace Surveillance: Your employer could be watching you
item.description: Read IFF’s public brief highlighting the impact of the Personal Data Protection Bill 2019 on workplace surveillance and participate in the consultation being held by the Joint Parliamentary Committee.

item.title: Educate and advocate for better privacy protection before the Data Protection JPC
item.description: Read SaveOurPrivacy.in’s analysis of the PDP Bill, 2019. This helps you form your views and participate in the invitation to public comments invited by the Joint Parliamentary Committee.

item.title: Security researchers need legislative protection for responsible disclosure
item.description: Security researchers, vulnerability testers and journalists need to be protected, especially when reporting on data breaches in India.

item.title: A cyber secure India, starts with securing Indians
item.description: Our submission to the National Security Council Secretariat for framing of the National Cyber Security Strategy 2020 (NCSS 2020) focusses on protecting individual privacy.

item.title: Here comes the Bill, all dressed in Nil #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: As the Data Protection Bill has made its appearance, we list out existing and new additions to our concerns with the Bill.

item.title: We ask the Committee on IT to let those targeted by Pegasus be heard!
item.description: We ask the Standing Committee to invite those affected by Pegasus to provide testimonials.

item.title: IFF submits comments to the Standing Committee on Science & Tech highlighting worries with the DNA Bill, 2019.
item.description: The DNA Bill has been re-introduced in the Lok Sabha and also referred to the Standing Committee on Science and Technology which has invited comments. We had a lot of comments.

item.title: While Delhi has its pollution mask on, the rest of India might need one too. For different reasons of course...
item.description: In light of the continuing growing concerns of CCTVs and facial recognition technology in the recent weeks, we throw a few more kicks to fight against this trajectory of mass surveillance.

item.title: NCRB finally responds to legal notice on facial recognition, we promptly send a rejoinder...
item.description: The NCRB promptly responds as we followed up on our legal notice and IFF replies having to restate original asks.

item.title: Here's looking at you/he/she/they! The UN Special Rapporteur on the right to privacy looks at gender and personality.
item.description: The UN Special Rapporteur on the right to privacy is exploring the importance of the right to privacy specifically its enjoyment based on gender and personality. IFF makes a submission with concerns and recommendations.

item.title: #PrivacySupreme: Two years of the Right to Privacy.
item.description: 24 August 2019 marks the second anniversary of the Indian Supreme Court’s landmark judgement in KS Puttaswamy v. Union of India. We celebrate and critically appraise this moment as we discuss our next steps in protecting the Right to Privacy.

item.title: Updates from the Supreme Court: Facebook's transfer petition of the Aadhaar-social media linking case in the Madras HC.
item.description: The Hon’ble SC issues notice to respondents, permits hearings to be continued in the Madras HC but directs that no final orders be given.

item.title: Personal Data and Information Privacy Code Bill, 2019 introduced in the Lok Sabha today! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF goes to Parliament with Dr. Ravikumar (Lok Sabha, MP from Tamil Nadu). Today, the Personal Data and Information Privacy Code Bill, 2019 was introduced!

item.title: Vanakkam! Updates on the Aadhaar-social media linkage and encryption PIL before the Madras HC
item.description: At today’s hearing, IFF placed on record its written submissions highlighting how proposed changes to the product design of social media platforms would harm user privacy and lead to over-broad automated censorship.

item.title: Legal notice to the Delhi Government to immediately halt CCTV installations.
item.description: As the Delhi Government begins installation of CCTV cameras, we write to the Chief Minister of concerns with its process and lack of safeguards.

item.title: We won’t give up! IFF approaches CIC against MHA’s refusal to disclose surveillance figures.
item.description: After the MHA rejected our RTI applications about use of surveillance powers on flimsy grounds, IFF has filed an appeal before the CIC and we are willing to go the distance in this fight for transparency.

item.title: Too many cooks won't spoil this broth. Need for larger participation by the Parliamentary Committee on IT.
item.description: As the Parliamentary Committee on Information Technology widens the ambit of its hearings to other online platforms, we ask them to ensure the inclusion of civil society organisations, academics and experts. We also raise some questions regarding the criteria and scope of these hearings.

item.title: Need for the Parliamentary Committee on IT to broaden participation and move towards outcomes
item.description: Next week the Parliamentary Committee on IT will hold a hearing on, ‘Safeguarding citizens’ data on social/online news media platforms’. It invites Government officials & Twitter. Public participation is necessary on this vital issue.

item.title: Explainer: How the MHA notification is another step in making India into a survelliance state #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: So has the government merely issued a routine notification empowering intelligence agencies to gather intelligence to prevent terrorism or is this the creation of a surveillance state?

item.title: “No more data collection without privacy protection” #DNABill #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: In the present winter session of parliment a key proposal impacting our privacy may pass into law. The, DNA Technology (Use and Application) Regulation Bill, 2018 is up for consideration & passage and we need to oppose it.

item.title: Winter (session) is here! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The winter session of parliament will start on December 11, 2018 in which important legislative business on privacy will be conducted across three key legislations.

item.title: The drafting process for the Data Protection Bill should not be shrouded in secrecy #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology has denied SaveOurPrivacy.in’s request for transparency in the drafting of India’s privacy law. We have filed first appeals under the RTI Act.

item.title: #SaveOurPrivacy initial statement on Justice Srikrishna Committee Report
item.description: Originally posted on SaveOurPrivacy.in The Expert Committee chaired by Retd. Justice B.N. Srikrishna submitted its 176 page report to the Minister of Electronics and Information Technology at 1600 Hrs on 27 July 2018 (today). The Committee also submitted a draft of the legislation on data protection titled, ‘The Personal Data Protection Bill, 2018’. After weeks of secrecy, denial of information in RTIs about the proceedings of the Committee, the report as well as the draft legislation have now been placed in public domain.

item.title: We call on the TRAI to protect user privacy in the Indian telecom sector!
item.description: Fresh off the historic nine judge decision of the Supreme Court holding privacy as a fundamental right, IFF has called on the TRAI to protect user privacy and data protection in its ongoing public consultation “Privacy, Security and Ownership of the Data in the Telecom Sector”. We previously posted a short summary of this consultation paper back in September. You can read our full November 6 comments to the TRAI here.
